timeline.message:
Trigger Release with tag 'releaseTrigger'

This changes will trigger a build on master,
when there is a tag 'releaseTrigger' created.

It will notify our normal GitHub Actions, and
retrigger a build. The payload will tell the
our normal build, that this is a release, and
it will trigger the build.

Downside, this will only work in MASTER for now.
If we want to support other branches, we need
to use our combined brain power, how to retrieve
a branch name from a git tag. It is not such
a trivial problem.

Trigger Release with tag 'releaseTrigger'

This changes will trigger a build on master,
when there is a tag 'releaseTrigger' created.

Downside, this will only work in MASTER for now.
If we want to support other branches, we need
to use our combined brain power, how to retrieve
a branch name from a git tag. It is not such
a trivial problem.

Trigger Release with tag 'releaseTrigger'

This changes will trigger a build on master,
when there is a tag 'releaseTrigger' created.

It will notify our normal GitHub Actions, and
retrigger a build. The payload will tell the
our normal build, that this is a release, and
it will trigger the build.

Downside, this will only work in MASTER for now.
If we want to support other branches, we need
to use our combined brain power, how to retrieve
a branch name from a git tag. It is not such
a trivial problem.

Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/issues/TagAction' into issues/TagAction

# Conflicts:
#	.github/workflows/actions.yml
#	.github/workflows/releaseTrigger.yml

timeline.bodyText: This means we wait for the build in actions.yml to complete successfully? Is that job uniquely identified, i.e. what happens if we ever add a third yml for whatever reason? Could this step here then be completed by that other job workflow?
timeline.author: nipafx
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+# This workflow will build a Java project with Gradle
+# For more information see: https://help.github.com/actions/language-and-framework-guides/building-and-testing-java-with-gradle
+
+name: Release
+
+on:
+  create:
+    tags:
+      - 'releaseTrigger'
+
+jobs:
+  deploy:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    name: releasing
+    steps:
+      - name: Wait for build to succeed
+        uses: jitterbit/await-check-suites@v1
+        with:
+          appSlugFilter: 'github-actions'
+          timeoutSeconds: '300'

replies.bodyText:
This means we wait for the build in actions.yml to complete successfully?

yes

Is that job uniquely identified, i.e. what happens if we ever add a third yml for whatever reason?

No currently we wait for all test suites which are running on the same git SHA to be finished, not one particular, but all checks from github actions

Could this step here then be completed by that other job workflow?

Not completed but it will be a necessary step to wait for
replies.author: aepfli

replies.bodyText: That's good to know (can you add a short comment explaining that?). I wondered whether we should try to limit this to the actual checks that are currently configured, but I think waiting for all to be successful (they need to be successful, right?) is safer. This way, when we add a new job, the worst that can happen is the release not getting triggered.
replies.author: nipafx

timeline.bodyText: The TRAVIS_ is necessary because of ShipKit, correct? If so, can you add a comment here that clarifies that?
timeline.author: nipafx
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+# This workflow will build a Java project with Gradle
+# For more information see: https://help.github.com/actions/language-and-framework-guides/building-and-testing-java-with-gradle
+
+name: Release
+
+on:
+  create:
+    tags:
+      - 'releaseTrigger'
+
+jobs:
+  deploy:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    name: releasing
+    steps:
+      - name: Wait for build to succeed
+        uses: jitterbit/await-check-suites@v1
+        with:
+          appSlugFilter: 'github-actions'
+          timeoutSeconds: '300'
+      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
+      - name: Setup java
+        uses: actions/setup-java@v1
+        with:
+          java-version: 8
+      - name: Perform Release
+        uses: eskatos/gradle-command-action@v1
+        env:
+          TRAVIS_BRANCH: master
+          TRAVIS_COMMIT_MESSAGE: <no commit message, not needed, we do not care about them, if we trigger or not>
+          TRAVIS_PULL_REQUEST: false

timeline.bodyText: This means a broken release requires manual cleanup of the tag. Would that be a reason to perform this step much earlier, i.e. as the first one?
timeline.author: nipafx
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+# This workflow will build a Java project with Gradle
+# For more information see: https://help.github.com/actions/language-and-framework-guides/building-and-testing-java-with-gradle
+
+name: Release
+
+on:
+  create:
+    tags:
+      - 'releaseTrigger'
+
+jobs:
+  deploy:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    name: releasing
+    steps:
+      - name: Wait for build to succeed
+        uses: jitterbit/await-check-suites@v1
+        with:
+          appSlugFilter: 'github-actions'
+          timeoutSeconds: '300'
+      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
+      - name: Setup java
+        uses: actions/setup-java@v1
+        with:
+          java-version: 8
+      - name: Perform Release
+        uses: eskatos/gradle-command-action@v1
+        env:
+          TRAVIS_BRANCH: master
+          TRAVIS_COMMIT_MESSAGE: <no commit message, not needed, we do not care about them, if we trigger or not>
+          TRAVIS_PULL_REQUEST: false
+          GH_WRITE_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GH_WRITE_TOKEN }}
+          BINTRAY_USER_NAME: ${{ secrets.BINTRAY_USER_NAME }}
+          BINTRAY_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.BINTRAY_API_KEY }}
+          NEXUS_TOKEN_USERNAME: ${{ secrets.NEXUS_TOKEN_USERNAME }}
+          NEXUS_TOKEN_PASSWORD: ${{ secrets.NEXUS_TOKEN_PASSWORD }}
+        with:
+          arguments: ciPerformRelease
+      - name: Delete Tag
+        run: git push --delete origin releaseTrigger

replies.bodyText: that is a really good question -> we also should think ob some kind of notification in the error case. Or we can also provide a flag, which will continue the job, even if it failed. That is something hard to tell, which we should define. I do not have any special preferences regarding that :)
replies.author: aepfli

replies.bodyText: I think it's bad enough that we abuse tags this way, we shouldn't go further and build an entire protocol based on them. 😉 The check marks next to each commit will show how the build went. Additionally, you can configure Bintray to send you an email for each release.
replies.author: nipafx

replies.bodyText:
I think we can use this feature:
https://help.github.com/en/actions/reference/context-and-expression-syntax-for-github-actions#job-status-check-functions
Per default, steps only run "when none of the previous steps have failed or been canceled". Using if: ${{ always() }} seems to be a good fit for clean-up tasks like this.
(Sorry, haven't found time for a full review so far.)
replies.author: beatngu13

replies.bodyText:
Per default, steps only run "when none of the previous steps have failed or been canceled". Using if: ${{ always() }} seems to be a good fit for clean-up tasks like this.

added
replies.author: aepfli

replies.bodyText: @aepfli could it be that you forgot the condition in your commit 254583d?
replies.author: beatngu13

replies.bodyText: you are right, sorry my bad -.-
replies.author: aepfli

timeline.bodyText:
Grammar Nazi: There are different capitalization styles in e.g. name an comments. For example:
"Wait for build to succeed" (Sentence case) vs. "Perform Release" (Title Case).

timeline.bodyText:
Should we have an additional restriction for master?
on:
  push:
    branches:
      - master
  create:
    tags:
      - releaseTrigger
timeline.author: beatngu13
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@

+
+name: Release
+
+on:

replies.bodyText: No there is no need for a trigger on master. We do not want to publish on master pushes, but as soon as the tag is created. So we can trigger a deployment without caring about commit messages
replies.author: aepfli

replies.bodyText: I always forget that tags are not bound to branches, but commits. 🤦‍♂️
replies.author: beatngu13
